MOUNTAINEER LEARNS OF
WAR AND IS GLAD TO GO
Uniontown, Pa., Sept. 7.-——‘‘Hell,

are we into the war?” asked Jacob
eredual (Harris after a moment of surprise.
“You don't have to force me to go.
My place is at the front using the
old shooting iron, I'm d-——glad IL
came to town.” Harris, a moun-
taineer, was making his first visit to
the city in four years when the police
learned that he had no registration
ecard. Harris was inducted into serv-
ice at once,

battle, but more upon the
crystallization of German nerve, The
hardest steel will yield under per-
sistent pressure. Victory depends up-
on the unstinted expansion of effort
to which all the allies are committed.

GREAT FRENCH GENERALISS!IMO

A CHANCE TO RECUPERATE.,
CROWN PRINCE BADLY BEATEN

Achievements of Khaki-Clad Boys
Heartens Stay-at-Homes to Buy
Fourth Liberty Bonds,

That was some drive which Marshal
Foch directed against the Hun when
he thrust them backward from the
Marne and sent them scurrying to
their new line of defense along the
Aisne,

Never for a moment did the Hun-
hungry poilus and Yanks stop their
dashing, smashing attack; never for a
moment did they give the baby butch-
erers a breathing spell; never for a
moment was there thought with any

one of them of anything but putting ;
| just as many Germans as possible per-
manently .out of business.

It was a world-thrilling exhibition of
stimulated by typical
Yankee punch.

It gave the Crown Prince his most
decisive defeat of the war. It set the
| Prussian-dominated press of all Ger-

many to camouflaging the situation, It
‘shook the German army morale and
sent the first thrill of apprehension up |

and down the spine of the whole Ger-
man empire. ‘
It probably intimated to Kaiser Bill

j ‘that after all the Lord was not alto-
ether halding up his end of the self- ,
appointed partnership. And it put new
upirit, new hope, new confidence into

every war-weary Allied heart.
The Biggest Drive of All.
dt was a magnificent thrust, but the
biggest anti-Hin drive of them all, the
one that will mean more to the Allied
cause than the last victory of the

Marne, that will pave the way for
onslaughts than '

more tremendous
ever, will begin on the 28th of Sep-
tember—the Fourth Liberty Loan
Drive.

We stay-at-homes could not partici-
pate in that gloriaus Marne victory,
but we can, evéry mother’s son of us,
lake part in this coming drive. We
can make our dollars fight for us. We
can show the world at large, our boys .

in the trenches and the German em-
pire in particular that the heart of
America is in this fight to the limit.

And if our loyalty is genuine, if our
patriotism is simon pure, if our sense
of duty Js thoroughly alive we will do
this.

Early we will begin laying aside for
eur next bond purchase.

We will save as they struggle, lend
as they fight.

And we will buy early, in order that
the war will be over quickly and our
boys over there be brought back over
here.
Eighth District’s Record,

The St. Louis District, which was
the first to go “over the top” in the
Third Loan, will make strenuous ef-
forts to be first in the Fourth Loan.
The organization throughout the en-
tire Eighth Federal Reserve District
is already complete, and there is no
question that the machine will be even
more efficient than it was on former
loan campaigns.
Opening of Fourth Campaign.

Secretary of the Treasury McAdoo
has officially fixed date for the open-
ing of the Fourth Liberty Loan cam-
paign as Saturday, September 28. The
campaign will be one week shorter
than the Third Loan, and will close
on Saturday, October 19,

COUNTRY 15 READY
FOR OPENING OF THE
FOURTH LOAN CAMPAIGN

Secretary McAdoo Returns to Desk
and Prepares for Next Bond
* Drive.

Secretary of the Treasury McAdoo
has returned to his duties in Wash-
ington after a vacation of two months
in the mountains west along the Pa-
cifie Coast, and at White Sulphur
Springs, Va. He spent the greater
part of his first day at the Treasury
Department, President Wilson went
over from the White House alone to-
ward 6 o'clock and joined the Secre-
tary, there, and the two engaged in
a long conference over pending ques-
tions of war finance and Federal ad-
ministration of railroads.

While at the Treasury Department,
Secretary McAdoo, met newspaper
ee and told them he had been won-
derfully benefited by his rest since
he close of the last Liberty Bond
campaign, and that he came back to
work feeling better in every way
than he had since he was a boy and
fished with a pin.

The Secretary said that his first
duty now was to take up exhaustively
‘the whole general subject of taxation.
He will meet with the Ways and
Means Committee, go over estimates
of moneys required and discuss with
the committee various forms of taxa-
‘tion and the different fields of sup-
port for the heavy rates that the exi-
gencies of war required should be
imposed.

Secretary McAdoo expressed full
reliance on the loyal sentiment of
_ business men and the income earn-
ers throughout the country. So long
as the manhood of the United States
is driving back the Germans, the peo-
ple at home, he said, would put up
the money to help them.
| He was not prepared td say what
‘the size of the next bond issue will
| be, nor could he give any idea until
he had had time to examine the prog-
‘ress that had been made by the Ways
| and Means Committee in arranging
the next tax bill.

He had been furnished no reason
to modify the estimates he had made
a month or more ago, was without
| definite information as to how far
the committee had been able to ad-
‘vance the tax line up to the mark set
in the estimates, he said,

Just as soon as the work of the
committee was completed, and the
volume of money to be provided by
, taxation could be determined, the
‘Secretary sald he would announce
the amount and the terms of the next
bond issue. Although no assurance
was given, there was no intimation,
in the secretary's statement that any.
change in the interest rate was con-
templated,
| The financial condition of the coun-
try, MeAdoo said, was never more
promising for the sale of bonds by
the Government than it is now, from
every means of information available,
either through official channels or
those of banking and private busi-
| ness.
German Desks Put to Good Use.

Desks on which German propag-
anda was formerly written are now in
use in the Liberty Loan Organiza-
tion, A. Mitchell Palmer, Alien
‘Property Custodian, at New York,

German banker,
propagandist, bomb plotter, and all
round undesirable citizen. The New
York Liberty Loan Organization will! priated to July 1, 1918,

use these desks in the campaign that
‘opens Sept. 28 for the Fourth Liberty
Loan.

What good is your money if we
don't win the war?
